theText: The Leader of the House can't organise the business as it is!
title: Representatives Main Committee

speaker: Mr Ronaldson
theText: I am surprised the honourable member for Port Adelaide interjectedMC 2504 MAIN COMMITTEE Thursday, 20 June 1996 Australian Sports Drug Agency, as defined by this amendment bill, are clear. The amendment will allow the agency to more effectively and efficiently deter the use of drugs or doping methods in sport. This bill also acknowledges that it is important to encourage the development of programs to educate the sporting community about matters relating to drugs in sport. Education is vital if we are to eradicate this unfair practice on our spotting fields. This bill also allows ASDA to advocate the adoption of a consistent and effective national response to matters relating to drugs in sport. Policies aimed at eliminating drugs in sport will only be truly successful and effective if there is an international effort to eradicate this problem. This bill further enhances ASDA's objective of enabling it to coordinate the development of a consistent and effective national response to matters relating to drugs in sport. The bill goes further and strengthens the functions of the agency. One such function which is enhanced is the agency's ability to develop and implement drug testing programs. We need a nationally coordinated response to maintain our high standard of action against drugs in sport. If we cannot get our own house in order then we have no right to judge other countries. It is precisely because Australia is so tough on drugs in sport that we have an international leadership role in this area. This bill outlines the agency's function as advocating the international development and implementation of consistent and effective anti-doping programs, and encouraging Australian national, state and territory sporting organisations and professional sporting organisations to develop and implement comprehensive and consistent anti-doping initiatives. This measure includes initiatives relating to the testing for the use of drugs and to education about matters relating to drugs in sport, as well as allowing the use of the services of the agency in accredited laboratories. As a result of this bill, the agency will also develop and implement initiatives that increase the skills and knowledge of people involved in sporting activities about matters relating to drugs in sport. Along with allowing the agency to advocate and support research inside and outside Australia about drugs in sport, the bill will further allow the agency to implement anti-doping arrangements. The bill encourages the establishment of the means for the carrying out, by departments and authorities of the states and territories, of initiatives relating to drugs in sport and of the means for cooperation with those departments and authorities, as well as nongovernment sporting organisations, to implement such initiatives. It is also important to remember that this legislation was not framed in isolation. Given the importance of having a truly national and international approach to drugs in sport, to have attempted to make legislation in this area without consultation and cooperation would have been unproductive, to say the least. The widespread consultation involved in this bill's framing included input from the Australian Olympic Committee, CAS-the national sporting organisation, the Australia and New Zealand Sports Law Association, and the Privacy Commission. This legislation also reflects the privacy and human rights principles laid down in other Commonwealth legislation. In particular, only those people who need to have access to information will be informed. The government has been concerned to protect the rights of athletes, and has built into the legislation certain appeal rights to ensure that athletes are protected. Thursday, 20 June 1996 MAIN COMMITTEE MC 2505 But being aware of the athletes' rights does not override the athletes' responsibility to compete fairly with their fellow athletes. This legislation will ensure that drug testing programs continue to deter athletes from using drugs, while at the same time ensuring that the rights of athletes who undergo testing will not be compromised. Furthermore, it is important to remember that this bill will reduce the likelihood of legal challenges which may result from an athlete returning a positive drug test. This bill should leave no doubt in the minds of all honourable members of the government's commitment, not only to the eradication of drugs in sport but also to the Australian Sports Drug Agency. Since its establishment, the agency has conducted more than 3,000 drug tests, and it is a testament to Australian athletes that 99 per cent of these tests were drug free. During my time as the shadow sports minister I had a lot to do with ASDA. In those days I had, and I still have, considerable respect for their expertise and professionalism. I am sure that view is shared by the minister. The agency also plays a highly commendable role in ensuring that our athletes can compete in fairer international competitions. During the past 12 months, the number of out-ofcompetition drug tests conducted by international sports has increased, I understand, by almost 50 per cent. The agency has carried out the drug testing programs for the World Swimming Championships, the South-East Asian Games, the World Weight-lifting Championships and a host of other major international sporting events. The government has also entered into anti-doping agreements with other countries, including the United Kingdom, Canada, France, New Zealand and Norway, as an acknowledgment of the importance of having a unified international approach to drug testing. Such multilateral agreements will lead to the establishment of an international benchmark for testing programs, utilising an internationally recognised system of accreditation and certification. It is therefore appropriate that Australia was the first non-European country to accede to the Council of Europe Anti-Doping Convention, which aims to harmonise anti-doping programs between countries. What the Australian Sports Drug Agency is essentially about, at both national and international levels, is ensuring that all athletes are given a fair go when competing. It is regrettable that there are some countries which still have athletes using performance enhancing drugs. One such country which has come under international scrutiny is China. This scrutiny is totally justified. For example, after the Hiroshima Asian Games, 31 Chinese athletes tested positive to banned drugs. To be fair, not only did the Chinese government respond to this by increasing the frequency of out-of-competition tests, but last August China passed a law making it a criminal offence to supply banned drugs to athletes, with a penalty of a four-year ban for athletes found guilty of taking these drugs. These new restrictions imposed by the Chinese government have started to have an effect. By the end of last year, Chinese officials had conducted nearly 2,100 tests, which is a 50 per cent increase on 1994. During that period, only 17 athletes tested positive, compared with 31 in 1994 and 23 in 1993. I believe it is appropriate that, if China is genuine in its commitment to ensure that its athletes are truly drug free in competition, China should call on ASDA to help achieve this aim. This is one of the reasons why a joint drug testing program was announced last December between Australia and China under which each country could conduct random tests on the other's athletes. This is a truly historic decision, meaning that for the first time Chinese athletes would be randomly tested outside of competition. MC 2506 MAIN COMMITTEE Thursday, 20 June 1996 I am sure that such moves to crack down on sports cheats-and athletes who take enhancing drugs are cheats-are welcomed by the Australian public. It was therefore with some concern that I read recent media reports which stated that the testing of Chinese athletes which I referred to earlier has not happened. As far as I am aware, ASDA is yet to conduct tests on Chinese athletes. I am not too sure whether these notes are out of date or whether the tests have indeed started. I hope they have. It is encouraging to hear that the agency is on the verge of going to China, although this may well be too late for the Atlanta Olympics. It must be remembered that almost every country, including China, has already chosen its team to compete in Atlanta. I would hate to think that an athlete who competed fairly could miss out on going to the Olympics-an honour that every professional athlete strives for-only to be replaced by an athlete who, it is later found, is taking performance enhancing drugs. Although welcoming ASDA's move into China, I fear that this will be too late for the Atlanta Olympics, as I said before. I note with interest that the head coach of the Australian swimming team, Don Talbot, has also recently expressed a personal view that he suspects drugs will be present at Atlanta, particularly in the Chinese women's team. I think it is a great tragedy not only for the competition but also for those who are competing. It is fair to say, however, that the great majority of athletes who are going to Atlanta have got there on their own merits, on their own abilities and, as such, should be congratulated. It is unfortunate, however, that there will be a minority amongst them who are too gutless to compete on equal terms, and instead have turned to drugs to help them along. It is unfortunate that such people will be unfairly performing against decent and honourable athletes. Hopefully, through the continued efforts of organisations such as ASDA, such athletes will be detected and dealt with accordingly. It is time for a little bit of parochialism, and I am sure that honourable members will allow me to indulge in it briefly. Athletes whose honest efforts, I hope, are not jeopardised in the representation of our country by those who are cheating include a number from my electorate. I can assure you, Mr Deputy Speaker, there are no drug takers amongst my constituent athletes. With your leave, Mr Deputy Speaker, it is with pride that I tell the House about the number of athletes who have come from Ballarat, a small region with extraordinary representation. Murray Hocking and Peter Blackburn are in badminton. Steve Moneghetti, the Ballarat Bullet, is, as I am sure you are aware, a Ballarat boy. Shaun Crichton is in athletics. Alison Cook, Robyn Maher and Ray Bomer are in basketball. Russell Mark is in trapshooting. Anthony Edwards and a recent addition to the Olympic team, Bronwyn Thompson, are in rowing, and Shane Kelly is in cycling. Although Shane comes from Ararat, I am sure I speak on behalf of the honourable member for Wannon( Mr Hawker) when I congratulate Shane Kelly and include him in the broader Ballarat region. Lots of terrific stories come out of membership of the Australian team. The Ballarat Courier reported recently that Bronwyn Thompson, who had just got into the Olympic team, rang her mother and said, 'Mum, it's not my phone and I can't talk long. We have made it, Mum. Start packing your bags.' Speaking as a parent with young children, any thought of any of them competing in the Olympics is a long way off, but it must really be an extraordinary thing for parents of Olympic athletes to receive such phone calls about their sons or daughters being chosen to represent their country. I am sure it is matched only by the extraordinary pride of those young--or youngish-people themselves. Thursday, 20 June 1996 MAIN COMMITTEE MC 2507 Competing at Atlanta will be a thrill, but I am sure that an even bigger thrill for Australian athletes will be to compete at the Sydney Olympics. At least at those games, Australia as a nation-and, more importantly, as a sporting nation-will be on exhibition for the world to see. We owe it to all athletes to ensure that they are the pinnacle of the drug free games. I have no doubt that our hard line on drugs in sport was one of the reasons we were given the honour of hosting the games. These Olympics will also give us an opportunity to show off the effectiveness of our domestic anti-doping programs and, in doing so, to advocate to the international sports community the need for similar efforts worldwide. I am proud to be part of a government which supports a comprehensive package of measures aimed at ensuring that the games are truly drug free, and I am sure that is a sentiment felt by all members of both sides of the House, and it is something we can take great pride in. Some of the measures that the government has implemented and will implement include a drug testing program that targets international athletes competing in tr;rining in Australia; the advocating of out-of-competition testing programs by international sports federations which target their top athletes on an annual basis; drug testing via programs by SOCOG at the 2000 Olympics and the test events leading up to the 2000 Games; maintenance of an internationally accredited drug testing laboratory in Australia; continuing research to ensure new doping practices can be detected; education programs throughout schools and sporting communities; anti-doping agreements between Australia and other governments; and measures to reduce the prescribing and illicit supply of performance enhancing drugs. It is encouraging to see that key organisations from the sport, health, education, law enforcement, government and non-government sectors will be taking up these measures. Agencies such as ASDA will only be truly successful if they have the cooperation of the athletes. Looking at the results of surveys, it is encouraging to see that our elite athletes believe that ASDA's drug testing program is likely to deter elite athletes from using prohibited drugs in sport. Our elite athletes also believe there is a high degree of accord with all aspects of the ASDA testing program, including the existence of ASDA testing and the conduct of ASDA personnel. It is interesting to note that 73 per cent of athletes from one of these surveys rated ASDA as being successful in balancing an individual's right to privacy with the need to maximise the deterrent effect of the drug testing program. The survey also found that the way ASDA works in the sporting community has received wide endorsement, with a majority of elite athletes believing ASDA consults successfully with the sport. The wide range of sources of information on drugs in sport used by elite athletes reflects a generally better informed and aware sporting environment. It should also be noted that 86 per cent of elite athletes believe that a national organisation independent of sport, such as ASDA, should be responsible for drug testing. The overall conclusion from the survey is that Australia's approach to the drugs in sport issue has been successful. It is legislation such as that before the House today which will ensure that this success continues. As we gear up for the Atlanta Olympics and especially the Sydney Olympics, it is legislation like this which provides an excellent blueprint for ensuring that Australian athletes can compete fairly against each other and their international competitors without threat of being unfairly challenged by those athletes who cheat on themselves and their country. I believe we can all be extremely proud of this nation's sporting history and I think we can be extremely proud of the fact that under ASDA we have taken the lead in the world in relation to drug free sport. MC 2508 MAIN COMMITTEE Thursday, 20 June 1996 There surely could be nothing more abhorrent to an athlete who has trained for three or four years, whatever it might be, in preparation for the Olympics or other major international sporting competitions to know that there is someone in the field who has enhanced their performance by the use of drugs. I think that, both as a nation and as an international community, we need to ensure that those who are competing at this level, at the highest level, are doing so on equal terms-not necessarily in terms of ability but in relation to the non-use of performance enhancing drugs. Finally, may I say, on behalf of all members, I am sure, that we wish our team at Atlanta the greatest of success. We are extremely proud of the fact that they have even reached the level where they can compete and I am sure we have all got our fingers crossed that they come back with a bag full of medals. But I do not think it is the medals necessarily that determine the outcome; it is the fact that a nation of Australia's size can compete at such an extraordinary level with nations whose populations are far larger and who it is fair to say, I suspect, put considerably more resources into sport than we as a nation do, and have done over a number of years. As I said before, we can be extremely proud of our team. Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Sydney 2000 Games) (12.18 p.m.)-in replyThis debate has raged over two sessions of the Main Committee. As outlined in my second reading speech, the Australian Sports Drug Agency Amendment Bill 1996 is designed to ensure that the Australian Sports Drug Agency can continue to undertake its responsibilities effectively and provide a leadership role in the international fight against the use of prohibited drugs in sport up to and beyond the 2000 Sydney Olympic Games. Both as Minister for Sport and also as Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the 2000 Games, I have a keen interest in the work of the agency. I would like to thank the participants in the debate, Mr Martin, the shadow minister, Mr Reid, Mr Cobb and Mr Ronaldson, for their contributions. All agreed that the work that has been done by ASDA has been exemplary in every regard. This bill, which clarifies a number of matters, enjoys the very strong support of the opposition and obviously the government. Indeed, the opposition, to its credit, started the work on the preparation of this bill prior to the election. It is absolutely essential that we position Australia in a very positive light in the world community, given that we are going to be hosting the 2000 Olympic Games. Mr Martin was concerned about the rights of athletes being protected. As one of the other speakers pointed out, there were extensive discussions with the Privacy Commissioner in the preparation of this legislation. Mr Reid was concerned to ensure that our assistance to China was able to be progressed, and indeed it is. He was particularly complimentary to ASDA. overview of drugs in sport and prohibited substances. He made a point, at the conclusion of his remarks, about appeals problems, ensuring that appeals can be heard expeditiously and so on. For the Atlanta Olympic Games there will be a court of arbitration. It will be able to hear matters within 24 hours and get results quickly to alleviate any problems that might emerge where there has been a positive response to drug testing or drug screening. Mr Ronaldson, the final speaker, gave a summary of the bill. He is a former shadow minister for sport. He worked extensively in that area prior to his illness. Now he is obviously fully recovered; he gave a fairly robust account of himself in here. He also indicated that extensive consultation had taken place between the Australian Olympic Committee, the Confederation
title: Representatives Main Committee

speaker: Mr Warwick Smith (Bass
theText: Minister f-r Sport, Territories and Local Government and
title: Representatives Main Committee

speaker: Mr Cobb
theText: who, interestingly, is a veterinary scientist by training-gave quite an extensiveThursday, 20 June 1996 MAIN COMMITTEE MC 2509 of Australian Sport, the Privacy Commissioner and the Australia and New Zealand Sports Law Association. He indicated his interest in the China issue and the difficulties that have been experienced in the past-we hope that they will be diminishing in the future-involving Chinese athletes and prohibited substances. I am hoping that the minister for sport from China will be participating in a visit program here in due course; we will be liaising closely with them. ASDA is already involved in discussions with the Chinese sporting federations on developing a drug testing regime for China. They have not started doing formal tests as yet, but that cannot be far away. In common with every other member of the House-and, I dare say, every senatorMr Ronaldson will be taking great pride in the Olympic athletes as they emerge in their particular areas. But he, like all of us, concluded with the view that it is best to be congratulating everyone on having got into the team. We will have our largest Olympic team ever going to Atlanta. He, like all of us, wants that team to do particularly well. Earlier in the week, I found out some information which was a little disturbing. I will take this opportunity, as it is the first I have had, to raise it. It was about an incident that took place on 17 February this year, involving a drug test that was undertaken here in Australia and had some repercussions that were very unfortunate for a particular individual. There was a Russian hammer thrower-Olga Kasinkova-who was able to record a world record under the rules of the International Amateur Athletics Federation. When one sets and reports a world record, one is required to have a full screening test and drug analysis before that world record can be accepted. Under the arrangements that we have in this country for doing the tests, there is a memorandum of understanding between my agency, ASDA, and the Australian Government Analytical Laboratories, who operate the Australian Sports Drug Testing Laboratory, which is accredited by the International Olympic Committee. What happened on this occasion was that the drug test was taken in and a half-screen test, rather than a full test, was done. By the time it was realised that the technical error had been made, the sample had been discarded. So we were unable to provide a full clearance under the rules of the International Amateur Athletics Federation, even though there was no positive testing at all, and this athlete's world record is not able to be recognised. Contact will be made with the Russian Athletic Federation and the athlete, apologising for the technical error. It gives an example of how careful we must be with our procedures. I will be having discussions with the minister responsible for AGAL, Mr Jull. This week we have instituted some administrative changes to ensure that this occurrence-which, I am advised, has never happened before-shall never happen again. We are making some changes which will involve the laboratory's entering into crosschecking of analytical reports with ASDA laboratory advice forms before despatching reports to ASDA and, subsequently, to the relevant international federations. Secondly, ASDA will do crosschecking of each laboratory report with the request made for specific samples, when in receipt of that report. Thirdly, the laboratory will retain the specific samples, in a frozen form, for an indefinite period-until directed to discard them by ASDA. That would overcome problems such as the one which occurred on this occasion and which, I might say, was very regrettable to the athlete concerned. There will be a redesigning of the advice form, to better highlight the selected options, and there will be automation of the system through bar coding, to eliminate human error. MC 2510 MAIN COMMITTEE Thursday, 20 June 1996 That is all that I am able to do to correct that particular incident, but I do want to make the point in this debate, given that there is very strong bipartisan support for what we are doing here, that, even with the best of motives and the best of intentions, sometimes there can be errors. When we find those errors in this very important area we will move very swiftly to correct them. We do feel very much for the particular athlete involved that that world record will not be recorded in the normal way and we will make sure it does not happen again. It will not, in any way, affect Australia's capacity to, as we have done, lead the world in drug testing for the world junior athletics championships to be held here in August or ultimately to be involved heavily in the detailed drug analysis work that will need to take place during the Sydney 2000 Games. Thank you for the indulgence to let me cover that matter. I commend the bill to the Committee and hope that it will be passed back to the House of Representatives without amendment. Question resolved in the affirmative. Bill read a second time. Bill-by leave-reported to the House without amendment. Consideration resumed from 17 June. Second Reading move: That the bill be now read a second time. On 19 April 1995, the High Court handed down its decision in the matter of Ridgeway v. The Queen. By a majority of 6 to 1, the court decided that where law enforcement officials use a controlled operation during an investigation into narcotics trafficking and, as a result, commit an element of an offence with which a defendant is charged, a court should normally refuse to admit the evidence of that element against the defendant. Some members of the court-Mason CJ, Deane and Dawson JJ, at page 58 of the report in 129 ALR-indicated that if law enforcement officers are to engage in unlawful conduct in the course of investigations, a legislative scheme authorising this conduct would need to be established. The bill that is now before the House responds to that judgment. Honourable members will recall that a bill to achieve the same purpose was introduced by the previous government; that bill lapsed when parliament was prorogued. The bill now before the House is based upon that previous bill but includes a number of significant improvements, as follows: the bill has been amended to ensure that controlled operations are used only for the purpose of investigating major unlawful activity. The important, but sensitive, power to conduct such covert operations will not be used for the investigation of minor criminal conspiracies; the accountability mechanisms will be significantly strengthened by incorporating the recommendations made last year by the Senate Legal and Constitutional Legislation Committee in its report on the 1995 bill; and
title: Representatives Main Committee

speaker: Mr Williams (Tangney
theText: Attorney-General and Minister for Justice) (12.27 p.m.)-IThursday, 20 June 1996 MAIN COMMITTEE MC 2511 a gap in the bill will be closed by protecting officers who are engaged in properly authorised controlled operations from the possibility of committing offences involving the importation, exportation or possession of narcotics contrary to the Crimes (Traffic in Narcotic Drugs and Psychotropic Substances) Act 1990. This was a possibility that was overlooked in the bill that was introduced into the parliament last year by the previous government. The bill now before the House also incorporates an amendment which was made when the bill was before the Senate. That amendment inserted a proposed section 15U into the bill. Proposed section 15U will require that a certified copy of the certificate authorising the conduct of a controlled operation shall be tendered in evidence in a prosecution for an offence against section 233B of the Customs Act-or an associated offence, such as conspiracy to import narcotics in contravention of that section-that depends upon evidence gathered by way of a controlled operation. This process will place the defence, and the court, on notice that such evidence will be led, and will enable the defence to prepare should it wish to test the process for authorising the controlled operation, and to contest the admissibility of that evidence. It will occur, albeit only occasionally, that a certificate will contain sensitive informationfor example, the name of a confidential informant--{)r information about a related but incomplete investigation. The contents of a certificate are specified in proposed section 15N. It was a deliberate decision by the government-and by the previous government in its bill last year-to require that the certificate contain a comprehensive statement of the relevant information. This is another aspect of the detailed accountability package which will surround the authorisation of a controlled operation. In those cases where a certificate does contain sensitive information which it would be unwise to disclose, it will be possible for the prosecution to seek to have that particular detail suppressed by making a claim of public interest immunity. This will ensure that, for example, other investigations are not compromised, or the safety of an informant is not endangered through sensitive information being disclosed. I should also make one other comment about the extensive debate in the Senate. This relates to the lengthy consideration of the issue of possible judicial authorisation for a controlled operation. This debate was prompted by an amendment moved by the Australian Democrats that would have required authorisation for a controlled operation by an 'eligible judge', being a judge of a federal court. This issue was considered exhaustively during the debate, with the result that the amendment was ultimately withdrawn by the Australian Democrats. Honourable members may be aware that when the House was considering the previous version of this bill in 1995, I suggested that consideration should be given to requiring judicial authorisation for a controlled operation. The then minister, the honourable member for Denison( Mr Kerr), opposed this proposal, speaking at length about the difficulties that this would involve. My remarks were made prior to the decision by the High Court in Grollov Commissioner for the AFP delivered on 21 September 1995. Obiter remarks made in that judgment indicate that the conferral of certain non-judicial functions upon judicial officers may well be unconstitutional, as being incompatible with the essential separation of powers which underpins our constitution. During the debate in the Senate, the government made available an advice by the Chief General Counsel of my department which indicates the dangers which may attend the conferral MC 2512 MAIN COMMITTEE Thursday, 20 June 1996 of such functions, particularly those that are related to the investigative process, upon judges. A further practical consideration is the recent reluctance by a growing number of Federal Court judges to issue warrants under powers given to them by the telecommunications interception legislation. I interpolate to say that I understand that 17 of the 44 Federal Court judges are respondents to proceedings in their own court. It has now become apparent that it is impractical, and may be constitutionally invalid, to empower a Federal Court judge to issue a certificate for a controlled operation. In the government's view, the bill now before the House represents the best and most practical way of responding to the High Court's decision in Ridgeway. I interpolate again to say that a case was argued in the High Court on Friday of last week which may provide an answer to the question as to the constitutional validity of the conferring of executive functions upon judicial officers. Apart from the changes to the bill introduced last year, which I have discussed, the general purpose and thrust of the bill now before the House remain the same. The bill will ensure that there is a legislative base for controlled operations by law enforcement agencies and that the officers participating in such operations are protected from criminal responsibility for conduct undertaken in the course of their duty. The bill will also provide an avenue for the admission of evidence obtained from controlled operations prior to its commencement, provided the operation was conducted in conformity with established procedures. Most importantly, the bill will provide a framework of accountability and control which will ensure that I, as the responsible minister, the parliament and the community have the opportunity to scrutinise the usage of this power by law enforcement agencies. Many people, both in the chamber and in the community, might ask: why should we sanction the police participating in criminal activity? I stress that parliament has already conferred upon law enforcement agencies the power to do certain things which, if done in the absence of that legislative authority, would be a criminal offence. The entry onto private property without the consent of the occupier is an offence of trespass; however, police may seek a warrant which will authorise such entry upon property. The detention of a person may amount to false imprisonment unless the detention is pursuant to a lawful arrest or other similar power. The bill presently before the House is in a similar vein to this type of legislation, which is in the best traditions of our system of law. Drug crime is peculiarly difficult to combat. Rarely are there complainants about this conduct. The importation of large quantities of drugs is a clandestine criminal activity involving complicity, or participants who will remain silent for fear of retribution. Organised crime does not tolerate complaint. As a result, the struggle against this trade involves very difficult choices for us as legislators and for the community. We are all committed to the preservation of fundamental values such as equality, privacy, freedom of expression, the right to a fair trial and so on. Equally, however, there is the right of the individual to protection by the state. There is a powerful public interest in opposing the spread of illegal drug trafficking, and the official corruption that it can spawn. Good law enforcement is a citizen's entitlement. It must be borne in mind that loss of confidence in law enforcement will lead governments to measures destructive of civil liberties. This is not such a bill. The choice before us is between a society prepared to accept balanced Thursday, 20 June 1996 MAIN COMMITTEE MC 2513 legislation to counter criminals, and a society poisoned by the conditions created by those criminals and their activities. The bill lays down a full and open system of accountability. The bill requires that the responsible minister, that is myself, is kept informed of all applications for a certificate conferring authority to conduct a controlled operation. I am also to be informed of the outcome of a controlled operation at the conclusion of the operation. In tum, I am required to table a report in parliament providing details of the applications made under the provisions of the bill and the outcome of the operations authorised under this legislation. The procedure will not lead to 'entrapment' of people. The bill will expressly provide that entrapment is not permissible. A controlled operation may be conducted only in circumstances where the targets of the operation are likely to import---or export-narcotics whether or not the operation takes place. The bill will ensure that it will not be permissible for officers to procure the commission of offences which otherwise would not have taken place. The consequence of a certificate being found to be invalid because the decision to issue was not properly made will be that evidence might be held to be inadmissible. That will be a matter for the court. However, it is not intended that the effect of this will be that a police officer who acted in good faith in reliance on the certificate would then be prosecuted. The situation would be different if a police officer dishonestly procured the issue of a certificate. The law as regards accepting or rejecting evidence obtained by improper methods will be maintained. However, controlled operations may lead to the detection of criminals whose activities might otherwise never be discovered, let alone prosecuted. I should emphasise that controlled operations are an internationally accepted investigatory technique. On 14 February 1993, the Convention against Illicit Traffic in Narcotic Drugs and Psychotropic Substances came into force in Australia. That convention was implemented by legislation that commenced operation that same day. Article 11(1) of the convention provides as follows: Article ll--Controlled delivery 1. If permitted by the basic principles of their respective domestic legal systems, the parties shall take the necessary measures, within their possibilities, to allow for the appropriate use of controlled delivery at the international level, on the basis of agreements or arrangements mutually consented to, with a view to identifying persons involved in offences established in accordance with article 3, paragraph I, and to taking legal action against them. This article indicates the recognition by the international community of the need to employ specialised investigative techniques, like the controlled operation, to deal with organised and sophisticated traffickers. In Australia the report of the Commission of Inquiry into Possible Illegal Activities and Associated Police Misconduct--commonly known as the Fitzgerald report-also discussed the use of new techniques in combating organised crime. Commissioner Fitzgerald concluded that an effective response to organised crime is dependent upon recognition of four factors: the social changes which crime causes and the fact that it diminishes the quality of life; the fact that crime escalates if it is not controlled; recognition that there are vulnerabilities in the social order which expose it to exploitation; and the steps that are needed to control crime. MC 2514 MAIN COMMITTEE Thursday, 20 June 1996 In relation to the latter point, Commissioner Fitzgerald stated that consideration should be given to a wide range of measures which would equip law enforcement agencies with new powers, including permitting 'the infiltration of criminal groups'. Commissioner Fitzgerald concluded that orthodox policing is quite unable to enforce the law. This bill will ensure that Commonwealth law enforcement agencies have available to them the controlled operation as a tool in the investigation of the trade in narcotics. I tum now to discuss briefly the key features of the bill. The central issue in the Ridgeway decision was the admissibility of evidence. The High Court held that because of the involvement of law enforcement agents in the importation of heroin, the evidence obtained thereby was fatally tainted and should be excluded from the trial of the principal conspirator. Honourable members may notice that the bill before them says nothing about the admissibility of evidence. How then, it might be asked, does the bill respond to the decision of the High Court? The basis for the decision by the majority of the High Court was that a trial judge has a discretion to exclude evidence on certain public policy grounds. The public policy ground in question, which then triggers the discretion to exclude evidence, arises where illegal police conduct is an essential ingredient of the charged offence. In such a case there will be 'an extremely formidable case for exclusion' of the evidence by the trial judge. The High Court accepted that the legislature could sanction the use of controlled operations and that such a legislative regime could exempt the officers from the requirements of the criminal law. The court went on to say that: ... in the absence of such a legislative regime, the courts have no choice but to set their face firmly against grave criminality on the part of anyone, regardless of whether he or she be government officer or ordinary citizen. The enactment of the bill now before the House will ensure that the actions of law enforcement officials engaged in a controlled operation will not incur criminal responsibility and, as a result, there will not be a trigger for the exclusion of evidence. It should be noted that the bill, whilst protecting the law enforcement officers from criminal responsibility, will still preserve the essential criminality or unlawfulness of the importationor exportation---of the prohibited narcotics. This will ensure that the importation or exportation itself is not made lawful, thereby exonerating the targets of the operation who planned the conspiracy. It is important to describe the effect of the bill upon prosecutions that are current at the time the bill commences operation. There are a number of investigations that are affected by the decision in Ridgeway. They all involve very significant participation in trafficking in narcotics, for example: conspiracy to import seven kilograms of cocaine---one individual; being knowingly concerned in the importation of 3.8 kilograms of cocaine-two individuals; being knowingly concerned in the importation of, and possession of, two kilograms of heroin-two individuals. I am advised by the Australian Federal Police that controlled operations were employed in each of these matters. These operations were strictly regulated and rigorously controlled covert operations. In each case they were conducted in purported accordance with the terms of a ministerial agreement relating to such operations and the detailed requirements of Australian Federal Police guidelines on the conduct of controlled operations. Thursday, 20 June 1996 MAIN COMMITTEE MC 2515 The ministerial agreement was entered into on 3 June 1987 between the then Special Minister of State-having responsibility for the Australian Federal Police-Senator the Hon. Michael Tate, and the then Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce-having responsibility for the Australian Customs Service-Senator the Hon. John Button. The agreement provided that a written request was to be made to the Australian Customs Service: ... where certain persons, goods, ships or aircraft, suspected or known to be carrying or having an involvement in drugs, are required by the Australian Federal Police or the National Crime Authorityto be exempted from detailed customs scrutiny and control and in cases where there is to be substitution of imported goods. Once that agreement was obtained, the operation was conducted in accordance with detailed requirements of the Australian Federal Police guidelines. These guidelines run to 50 paragraphs and closely regulate the considerations that should be adverted to when deciding whether a controlled operation should be conducted; the level at which operations must be approved; the procedures for a controlled delivery involving the substitution of the narcotic substance; further procedures for those operations where substitution is not feasible or possible; the requirements for analysis of the narcotic substance; and the making of payments to couriers and informants. These operations were conducted pursuant to these guidelines. The operations were closely monitored. Each of the accused alleged to have been detected as a result of these controlled operations is entitled to a fair trial and the presumption of innocence. But without the passage of this legislation those trials will have to be abandoned. I believe the community would not see that to be a just outcome. In conclusion, I believe that the community expects that law enforcement agencies will make every effort to catch the ' Mr Bigs' of organised crime, not just apprehend couriers and the dealers on our street comers. Indeed, the community has a right to expect, to demand, that law enforcement agencies will act to protect them and their children, who are particularly vulnerable. This bill will satisfy that demand by providing a firm legislative basis for the use of controlled operations as a device in combating drug trafficking. Other aspects of the legislation are described in the explanatory memorandum relating to the bill. I commend the bill and present the explanatory memorandum to the House. shadow Attorney-General and Minister for Justice, Senator Nick Bolkus, had this to say in relation to the Australian Labor Party's position on this bill: The objective of this legislation is one that we are very deeply committed to. Further on he said: The principle, the objectives and much of the structure of this bill we want to see in place. The only question is which is the best way to go and what accountability mechanisms are appropriate and can be appropriately invoked for this. It is fair to say that that has characterised the debate by all parties since this bill was first introduced when we were in government. Indeed, it was a bill that was strongly sponsored by the then Minister for Justice, the honourable Mr Duncan Kerr, the current member for Denison, and he will be speaking in the debate later and lending his full endorsement to the bill.
title: Representatives Main Committee

speaker: Mr Melham (Banks) (12.46 P.m.)
theText: In the Senate on Wednesday 29 May 1996, theMC 2516 MAIN COMMITTEE Thursday, 20 June 1996 From the initial introduction of the bill in the last parliament until now there have been a number of amendments. From my point of view-and it is acknowledged across the spectrum-those amendments are an improvement to what was originally put to the parliament and I applaud the Attorney-General and Minister for Justice( Mr Williams) for those amendments. There are some of us on both sides of the House that still have some reservation about aspects of this bill. That needs to be looked at in context. I think the Attorney-General was right when he said that there are different principles involved here. As law makers we reaIIy need in some instances to compromise; you cannot be pure one way or pure the other. There are practical difficulties and we need to acknowledge them. This bill certainly has had a lot of scrutiny. It will not satisfy some sections of the community; there will still be reservations about certain aspects. In that respect I would obviously counsel the Attorney-General and Minister for Justice to continue to monitor the operations of this bill because I fear, and I hope it does not come to pass, events will necessitate our revisiting this. WhatI am now presenting are personal reservations. I want to put them on the record, acknowledging that I will be supporting this bill, as will the opposition wholeheartedly. The time has come to pass it; I do not think that we are going to be able to satisfy everyone's concerns. Indeed, at one stage the Democrats in the Senate put in some amendments that related to the concept of external accountability and the Labor Party was prepared to support those amendments. When they were withdrawn we understood why they were withdrawn. It is a debate between people who are trying to achieve the same purpose. My reservations are encapsulated by some of the civil liberties groups. It goes back to the agreement provided on 3 June 1987 between the then Special Minister of State, Senator Michael Tate, and the then Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, Senator John Button. The minister in his second reading speech cited that section of the agreement. I think it is worth revisiting. The agreement provided that a written request was to be made to the Australian Customs Service: . . . where certain persons, goods, ships or aircraft, suspected or known to be carrying or having an involvement in drugs, are required by the Australian Federal Police or the National Crime Authority to be exempted from detailed Customs scrutiny and controland here is the crunch partand in cases where there is to be substitution of imported goods. So the original agreement reaIIy related to where goods were substituted, not the actual importation of illegal substances.What has happened as a result of the Ridgeway decision, I think it is fair to say, is that the authorities are receiving a bonus out of this legislation. That is where my concern is. I think there is a point where it is inappropriate for the authorities to be not monitoring and reacting, which is what I prefer. I do prefer a monitor, react and substitution situation, rather than allowing people within the authorities to engage in the importation as part of a controlled operation. It is just something I would caution, because the last thing I would like to see is authorities engaging in a controlled operation and not having substitution there, and those goods going astray. That is where the problem will arise: that if there is a controIIed operation in the future and it involves a large amount-and I am not talking about entrapment here-the authorities leave themselves open. But I recognise that it is not a perfect world. Thursday, 20 June 1996 MAIN COMMITIEE MC 2517 The other reservation was police authorising police. That is where some people in the community took the view that we should adopt what is in the Telecommunications (Interception) Act to allow judicial authorisation. I acknowledge what the Attorney has said, that members of the judiciary are not all that happy with that and that there is a case before the High Court to do with the Hindmarsh Island situation and involving Her Honour Justice Jane Matthews. SoI think that will see a further evolution as to whether the obiter that is in Grollo's case is, in fact, going to be the pronouncement by the High Court or not. So it is an evolving situation. In the end, no side is going to achieve totally what they want. There is a balance in this bill. I think the authorities can legitimately say, 'If the politicians want us to successfully stop the big importers, then we need these sorts of powers. We need legislative endorsement.' Basically, that is what the High Court said: if they are to engage in them, they need legislative endorsement. The Labor Party is lending its support. This is really something that is not party political, it is not crossing political boundaries. It is people genuinely having different views. My background is one of a defender; I have never prosecuted in my life. I must say that I have a particular view, and it is based on personal experiences. Others, like my colleague the honourable member for Denison( Mr Kerr), have engaged in prosecutions; they have appeared on both sides of the fence. It is fair to say that he is probably more objective and balanced than myself when it comes to the criminal code. It is fair to say that I tend to err on the side of the accused in terms of keeping those mechanisms in place. I subscribe to the view that it is better that 99 guilty go free, than that one innocent person is convicted. What frightens me is that, in the climate we have at the moment where you do have commentators who are uninformed, we get some bad cases and what happens is that bad cases make bad law and we go to the lowest common denominator. I am not saying that about this legislation. The time has come for it to pass through the parliament. But I have put these reservations on the basis that what I would like to see-and I am sure it will happen anyway-is a monitoring of the situation. If the situation is out of control, it needs to be looked at. If it is a situation where the police forces themselves are vulnerable when these matters come into court because it is authorisation of police on police and so acquittals are occurring because of suspicions-and it is not hard to put that into the arena-then we might need to look at some other form of external authorisation. That is something that will only evolve with time. I am glad the Attorney-General has included in the legislation the amendment that ensures controlled operations are used only for the purpose of investigating major unlawful activity. I know the honourable member for Dickson( Mr Tony Smith) will have something to say on this in the debate. I suppose it is really in the eyes of the beholder. My view of major unlawful activity is a little different from that of other people's. I would like this legislation to be used to catch those people who are higher up the chain rather than to pick up someone down the chain. In my view, if it is not substitution and not just a monitoring and reacting situation, this situationwhich allows the authorities to engage in what would otherwise be illegal activities-should be used sparingly. It should be reserved for those in the community whom we believe are engaging in criminal behaviour and not for those at the lower end of the scale. This is something that only time will tell; I am not here to be a prophet of doom. MC 2518 MAIN COMMITTEE Thursday, 20 June 1996 I did not speak on this in the last parliament. Because of some aspects of the bill at that time, I took the view that silence was golden. In my position, I felt this was the best thing I could do. I appreciate the fact that the Attorney-General played a role in the previous debate in the last parliament. I understand his role and I have every confidence in the role that he will playas Attorney-General as far as this legislation is concerned. To digress, I welcomed the appointment of Mr Williams as the Attorney-General and Minister for Justice. I do not think the Prime Minister, Mr Howard, could have made a better appointment for this particular office. I think his performance has been impeccable. I have one reservation, which I would like to put on the record, and it comes from someone with a legal background. I think the minister should be in cabinet. I come from that old school that says that the role of the Attorney-General is not that of a normal minister. The Attorney-General should be in cabinet; he should be giving proper legal advice to the cabinet. At times, this means that the Attorney-General is unpopular. He is not meant to be a populist; he is there to provide proper advice. He is there to restrain the rednecks in parliament and in the community; he is not there to adopt the populist view. As far as the constitution of the cabinet is concerned, the quicker the Attorney-General and Minister for Justice gets into the cabinet, the better. I will leave it at that. principle that silence is golden. I commend that to him during question time. I have defended on all but one occasion in 13 years of legal practice. I can assure you that I did not enjoy the one occasion on which I prosecuted. This bill comes-and I do not say this disrespectfully-from the prosecutorial side of things, so it is important to get the balance and the experience from the other side of the bar table. My particular experience involved a case that left an indelible mark on me and this has necessarily excited my interest in this particular bill. I seek leave to table the case. I do not want to mention it by name. I will refer to it as 'M', if I may, Mr Deputy Speaker. Leave granted. then relate it to the bill before the House. In that particular case, there was a major drug operation in Queensland. As a result of that major operation, to my knowledge only one person was netted, and that was M. The operation extended over many months. It cost the community hundreds of thousands of dollars and the result that was produced was less than satisfactory. Of the person M for whom I appeared, I can only say this. Having spent numerous hours with the person when I was in conference with her and so forth, I thought I had heard it all before until she came to give her evidence on the voir dire. Hearing her evidence in chief on the voir dire was enough to move me to tears, because it was an unbelievable story. The case extract does not fully illustrate it, but it illustrates it to a large extent. I am concerned that this is the sort of case that might be caught by the bill. In that particular case, the undercover police officer received an indemnity from the Attorney-General. The indemnity said this: that no prosecution or indictment will be brought or continued against RR being the undercover police officer-
title: Representatives Main Committee

speaker: Mr Deputy Speaker
theText: I observe that the honourable member for Banks adheres to the
title: Representatives Main Committee

speaker: Mr Tony Smith (Dickson) (12.59 P.m.)
theText: Like the member for Banks( Mr Melham),
title: Representatives Main Committee

speaker: Mr Tony Smith
theText: I would like to refer as quickly as I can to elements of that case andThursday, 20 June 1996 MAIN COMMITTEE MC 2519 in respect of any act or omission reasonably and necessarily done or made by him in the execution of his duty as a police officer and in the course of the police operation codenamedI will leave that outand I do hereby indemnify him accordingly. By way of background, the accused gave evidence on the voir dire. The voir dire is a trial within a trial. It is where the judge has to determine admissibility. This is important in the context of the bill. The defendant, or the accused, had to satisfy on the balance of probabilities that the evidence was unfair-in other words, that the evidence that was to be adduced against her was unfair, so therefore, she had to satisfy the judge on the balance of probabilities that it ought to be excluded. It is important to bear that in mind. As I understand the law even now-and the law that will apply here-if the same situation arises, the onus on the voir dire will be with the defendant. It is all very well to say, 'But ultimately, it is "beyond reasonable doubt"'. But if you cannot get past the voir dire, you go into the trial on the evidence. In the case of people who are caught in these nets, they frequently have a criminal history as long as your arm. Once they are raising unfairness and putting in issue the credit of the police officer, their history comes before the jury and they are gone. They are gone! The jury are not interested any more in the defence side of the case. That is the problem. It does concern me. This woman was 36 years of age at the time of this operation. She was introduced to marijuana when she was 13 and later to speed and acid. She was introduced to heroin when she went to university. She tried on numerous occasions to detoxify; she made a suicide attempt when she was 20. Her attempts to detoxify led to her being introduced to other drugs. She had an injury to her back, exacerbated by a car accident. The degree of pain was intolerable; this led her back to drugs. She had a sexual attack upon her where she was dropped on her head at Bondi. She suffered violently from pelvic problems-this was at the time of the trial. She had had a number of violent relationships with men. She had a history of prostitution, but she had, in her earlier days, excelled as a student. She had great potential but was held back. She had been involved with people who had died over the years from drugs and so forth, but she came to Queensland to get away from the drugs. In the latter part of 1988, she had an accident in which she hit a little boy. The consequences of that were not very serious, but that led her to try to commit suicide again, because this is the way she was---constantly in depression. She took up with a friend who had also been in drugs, and this friend was then approached by the undercover police officer. There was no suggestion that she was dealing in drugs in any way, shape or form, other than that she used to smoke marijuana for pain. That is what she did. On a scale of one to 10, her pain level was somewhere about eight all the time. That was the medical evidence. So what do you do when you are a drug addict, or a former drug addict, and you have that sort of pain problem? She was on methadone at the time, and she was going to university, trying to re-establish her life. Then this individual came into her life. This individual, on the pretext that he was dying of cancer and was a small-time dealer, fed his way into her life. She fell in love with him, and she would do anything that he said. So he inveigled her; he pressured her; he would constantly provide marijuana to her to smoke. Because the story seemed to hang together, it went on. In the meantime, unbeknown to the undercover police officer-she did not know he was undercover, of course-she was seeing a psychologist and was saying quite the opposite: 'He MC 2520 MAIN COMMITTEE Thursday, 20 June 1996 is trying to get me into drugs. He is trying to get me drugs. I do not want to, but I love him.' All of that evidence came out as part of it. It was a thoroughly dreadful case. His Honour made the following findings. She had been a heroin addict for many years in Sydney and moved to try to overcome it. She had serious medical, psychiatric and psychological problems, for which she had received treatment and counselling prior to 1989 and for which she was still receiving treatment. She had formed a close association with another drug addict, F, because it was difficult to find other social contacts with people who had not had a background similar to hers. She had used marijuana primarily to cope with her severe medical, psychiatric and psychological problems. She was strongly dependent on other people and prone to depression, with suicidal tendencies. She had taken a number of measures to deal with her problem. She had been a participant in the work of the alcohol and drug dependency unit and had resumed her university studies. These matters were known, at least to a substantial degree, by the undercover police officer. He cultivated the friendship, His Honour found, through this other person and sought to promote the friendship through frequent social contacts. The emotional attachment started. Cannabis was used frequently on those contacts. So it goes on. But time is eluding me. As a result of that, she was used to obtain a source of supply of cocaine in Sydney. One of most hideous aspects of all of this was that when this cocaine was brought back he gave her a cut of that cocaine. Was that necessary to the indemnity? I would say absolutely not, and I believe the man should have been charged with an offence, because it was not necessary to the indemnity to give her a cut. I further say-although His Honour did not find this-that I am absolutely satisfied that heroin was also supplied to her. So, by virtue of all of that evidence, His Honour found it was unfair, and he excluded all of the relevant evidence. So, ultimately, she walked from the court. I hope she has resumed her life to a large extent. The last time. I heard, she had done that, after a lot of difficulty getting over all of this and the shock, too, of being told that this person she was in love with was actually a police officer who had been using her for nearly a year. I will get to the bill very quickly now. it is in a different context from 15M-the words used are 'the person would not otherwise have had the intent to commit that offence or an offence of that kind.' The word 'would' is used, and I ask you, Mr Deputy Speaker, to bear that in mind. The words 'the intent' I have a bit of a problem with too. Should it say 'an intent'? I will leave that aside for a moment. The words are again used in subsection (5) of that same section-'would not otherwise have had the intent' . We then come to this critical section, 15M, which relates to the certificate authorising a controlled operation. Part (b) of section 15M says: the person targeted by the operation is likely to commit an offence ... I caution those who have presented this bill, and I do so with the greatest respect to those on both sides of the House who have expressed views on this, about the use of those words. It is my submission that the word 'would' is a far better word to use there. The reality is that the Mr Bigs are rarely, if ever, caught. We know that that is the intention. We know that

theText: I am delighted to hear that.

speaker: Mr Tony Smith
theText: I am laying the founuation. In the bill, in section 15I(2)(b)-I knowThursday, 20 June 1996 MAIN COMMITTEE MC 2521 is what we are trying to do. But, frequently, as happened in this case, it is the person at the very bottom-the broken-down, sad, tragic person-who is caught in this web, and that is my concern. That then goes to the issues on the voir dire, and the onus of proof and the problems there. It is all very well to say, 'If you provide a test like that, the jump is too high'. However, we have to have something that can rectify that onus of proof problem. Indeed, it may be worthwhile considering whether the onus on the voir dire in a case such as this should be on the prosecution. That would go some way to alleviating the problem, again, on the balance of probabilities, as it always is. At the moment, it is on the defendant. Alternatively, we could look at the use of the word 'would' in light of what, to me, seems a somewhat inconsistent use in the earlier section of the word 'would'. I know that it is a separate area. It is a certificate in one area but, nonetheless, we seem to be departing slightly and we leave it open. I think my time has run out but I do urge caution in relation to the matter. I have reservations. I believe the member for Banks has identified in broad terms that we have to monitor it carefully. But, bear in mind, as I said before, that people like M could be caught in the same situation. At the end of these operations, where hundreds of thousands of dollars have been spent, we all know that someone has to be prosecuted, and frequently it is that person.
